Expectation1: Support each other emotionally during tough times
Situation1: One sibling has just received some very difficult news and is deeply distressed by it.
Expectation2: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation2: A I04iend on their way to the airport calls, thinking they left their passport at home, and asks if you can check and bring it to them right away.
Story:
I was sitting on the couch, holding my sister’s trembling hand as she tried to process the news she’d just received. Her eyes were red, and she kept squeezing my fingers, searching for comfort. I knew she needed me to stay, to listen, to just be there for her. That’s what we always promised each other—no matter what, we’d be each other’s anchor in the storm.

My phone buzzed. It was Sam, my closest friend. His voice was frantic—he was already halfway to the airport and thought he’d left his passport at home. He begged me to check and, if it was there, to rush it to him. He couldn’t miss this flight; it was for his grandmother’s funeral. I could hear the desperation in his voice, the same kind of panic I saw in my sister’s eyes.

I felt torn in two. My sister needed me right here, right now. But Sam was counting on me, too, and I knew how much this meant to him. My heart pounded as I looked from my sister to my phone, feeling the weight of both their needs pressing down on me.
